Should virtually all Exams be Open Book? 
 
 This question always struck me as a really nice imaginary thing.
 
 Now, that I've been out of college for many years, the question remains, and I believe it remains valid.
 
 Tests can be designed to prevent so much use of an opened book that anyone not highly familiar with the subject can be made to fail, by use of time constraints.
 
 However, even in a test that has time constraints, I see no reason to not permit the test to be open book.
 
 Once you get past the rote material we all must know, it would be useful for everyone to recognize that in almost all professions, there are reference materials that can and are used often.
 
 For example, as a Software Developer I very often make use of online help to locate certain commands, and get the correct syntax, and look up specifics.
 The idea of being a walking dictionary is not a very creative or useful one.
 
 Look at professions like, law, medicine, mathematics, and physics and the piles of books they have, and require. 
 
 Remember in math the meanings of sine, cosine, tangent, and what side of the triangle goes over the other for all of the other trigonometric ratios?
 
 Well, to my way of thinking, if you know how to use sine, cosine, and tangent, that is what is important. It is NOT important to remember which side of the trainge goes over the other. That can be obtained from a book, moreover it is built into all calculators.
 
 Are there differing views on this, or have I just brainstormed why the SATs and the tests you get in school should be open book. Am I so open-minded that I've missed something which educators feel should not be done????

 Two problems:
 
 #1 Tests act as a guage. If your distribution is not bell-curve, your gauge is not good. Open-book tests are not a good gauge.
 
 #2 It IS important to know things, from memory, it's far, far more efficient. We humans have a finite amount of time, time is money, and most problems have a finite amount of time to be solved, else, consequences follow. All things equal I would rather hire someone who not only knows how to research, but actually retains what they research, vs someone who can't retain what it is they research, or who don't know how to commit things to memory effectively.
 
 I also want someone who committs themselves to the common goal of whatever it is they are hired for. All things equal, one of the only ways to differentiate who cares, and who doesn't care, is to look at their performance. Did they do they bare minimum or did they excel? 
 
 If you think it's better to use references than memory, do this.
 
 Strip your PC of all but the minimum memory required to run. Then let the rest hit the disk cahce, which works, but runs at a fraction of the speed the memory does. After waiting 5 minutes for an application to perform a 10 second calculation, give me a ring and ask for closed book tests back :)
